REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS STATE OF NEBRASKA Auditors Office ■ Lincoln, Nebr., Dec. 15, 1930. To the Honorable Arthur J. Weaver, -...':. Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska. Dear Governor: In compliance with Statute 4847, I take pleasure m presenting herewith my biennial report, covering the two years from July 1, 1928 to June 30, 1930. The statement of the. states Liabilities and Resources Us required by Statute 4847 you will find on page 7, showing resources totaling $81,263,381.23 with no state indebtedness. Compared with 1928 this is an increase m resources of $7,283,617.75. STATE FINANCES IN EXCELLENT CONDITION I am pleased to direct your attention to the splendid condition of the state Treasury as shown by the statement appearing on page 8. The cash on hand m the State Treasury on June 30, 1930 totaled $7,532,903.22 of which $2,816,987.31 belonged to the General Fund, or $2,436,496.84 after deducting the outstanding warrants. I am sure this is the largest General Fund balance remaining m the State Treasury at the close of any fiscal year m the history of the state. Further, there are now ho Cash Funds merged with the Gen - eral Fund. All on hand m this fund is available for the payment of expenditures authorized to be made from the_General Fund. On page 108 appears a summary of the 1927-2!) appropriations that lapsed and remained unexpended June 30, 1930, totaling $97, - -000.72, thuß reducing the liabilities of the General Fund. RECEIPTS AND EXPENDITURES Statements of the receipts and expenditures appear on pages 20 to 23 and a comparative classified statement covering the receipts and expenditures during the years 1922 to 1930 inclusive appears on page 43. By grouping the capital outlay and amounts expended for roads and bridges separately and separating the legislative expenditures and the disbursements from Trust Funds, the ordinary cost of run - ning the state is set out.

Misc.lfmHuj Rntfut — — — OpblOuKn md Puilit lm^wtmtnlj ■ . from U S. ' ' A great relative change has- taken place m the state's revenues as far as the sources of income are concerned. In 1922 the property tax constituted about 66 per cent of the total revenue and ' the miscel - laneous receipts about 17 per cent.: In 1930 the property taxes had dropped to less than 3 2 per cent while the miscellaneous receipts had increased to 53 per cent. :-.-.;■■ • ■ ■ . • SUBDIVISIONS REDUCE INDEBTEDNESS • I The bonds issued by the various subdivisions of the state during the Biennium July 1, 192S to June 30, 1930, totaled $12,090,675.45 as shown by statement No. 8, appearing on page 139. This is a de - crease of $4,743,108.55 compared with the preceding biennium. The bonded indebtedness of subdivisions, arranged by counties, are shown on statement 9 (pages 163-166) and the amount of bonds outstanding on June 30, 1930 totaled $109,884,868, which is a re - duction of $3,624,594 from the total outstanding two years ago. This reduction of indebtedness is very gratifying, indicating fundamentally sound conditions m the State: Very respectfully yours, . L. B. JOHNSON, LBJ:MM State Auditor.

WHEREAS, from tlie Auditor's report it appears there was ap - propriated to be paid out of the general fund the sum of 15,053,785.80 one-half of which should be met for the current year, which is $7, - 526,892.90 and WHEREAS, the Supreme Court of Nebraska has decided that the sum of $470,500 should be provided for in addition to-the above, and WHEREAS, the Supreme Court of Nebraska has decided the sum. of $260,111.34 appropriated for Reimbursement of depositors in failed banks and which sum was levied by this Board in 1929 is not a valid appropriation making a net increase of $210,38S.64 to be levied in addition making the total amount to be raised for the current year $7,737,281.54 To meet which it is estimated there will be available miscellaneous collections for the general fund not otherwise appropri - ated $1,142,339.92 General Fund collections to be de - rived from intangible taxes :. 219,823.71 1,362,163.63 $6,375,117.93 Which amount is increased 3% in ac - cordance with House Roll 189, Session . Laws of 1927 191,253.53 Leaving to be raised from the 1930 . . General Fund Levy $6,566,371.46 ■ The assessed value of the tangible property of the state as of record in the office of the State fax Commissioner $3,102,050,571 A levy of 2.12 will raise ..: t $6,576,346.00 The Capitol Fund levy as fixed by law is .22 of one mill and on the assessed valuation of the State will raise $ 682,452.00 THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, that the levies for 1930 be as follows: GENERAL FUND ...: 2.12 Mills " $6,576,346.00 CAPITOL FUND 22 Mills 6S2.452.00 TOTAL 2.34 Mills $7,258,798.00
